utterances: The military won't tell us about what they look like, what state they were in.
The details that we've been getting so far have been from Iraqis.
The bodies were all brought to a hospital in Baghdad to be identified.
And according to doctors, most of them had bruising, which might have indicated that they were likely strangled to death.
There were other bodies found in other parts of the capital.
The Iraqi police found six more bodies, and explosions in the capital killed at least four other people, including two young boys.
And the U.S.
military also reported today the death of an American solider who was killed in Tal Afar, a town that's near the Syrian border.
And U.S.
troops have been carrying out a lot of operations against insurgents there.
What is going on, politically, that would be the long-term hope, if there's any, in Baghdad?
Tell us what the situation is, politically.
Well, as you know, there has been a stalemate.
It's been nearly three months since the elections.
And since then, there has been a lot of back and forth between the different factions about who had won the most seats, you know, there were allegations of fraud.
And the Shiite alliance, which has won the majority of seats, nominated Ibrahim al-Jaafari as their choice for prime minister.
And the Sunni and the Kurdish factions have come out lately and said, no, we don't want him.
He's not good enough for the job, and we want someone else.
And President Jalal Talabani was trying to push this and give the Shiite alliance an ultimatum, and doing that by recalling parliament.
And finally, today, actually, not even too, you know, too long ago, we just discovered that the second vice president, whose signature was missing from this presidential decree, has just signed.
So, Talabani is now able to go ahead with that.
Putting parliament in place now actually sets the clock ticking on a 60-day deadline to get a new prime minister, get a new president.
And everything else that finally gets, you know, into the whole process of running the country, and hopefully trying to restore some stability on the ground.
NPR's Jamie Tarabay talking with us from Baghdad.
Appreciate it.
Thank you.
But first, it's March and that means madness, as in college basketball.
This weekend the field for the NCAA Tournament will be selected and all this week teams are trying to win that one last game that will earn them an invite.
But there's another basketball tradition we want to discuss now, rushing the court after big wins.
It's drawn concern from some school administrators.
NPR's Mike Pesca went courtside to bring us this report.
Wednesday night, Hackensack, New Jersey, there was smoke on the water, a fire in the sky, and a fevered glint in the eyes of the Fairleigh Dickinson students.
The only thing that stood between their team and a trip to the NCAA Tournament was the Monmouth Hawks.
The only thing in between the crazed crowd and the court itself was one flimsy barrier and a student in a gray t-shirt that read Event Staff, Denise Thompson.
Oh, if we win we're going to be all over the court.
And tell me about--describe this white barrier, how strong is it?
It's strong enough to stay up there by itself, but it's not strong enough when you have a thousand students running over it.
Can you lift it?
Yeah.
I can lift it up with both my hands, one hand, two hands, finger.
And she did lift the plastic barrier with a finger.
From a fan's perspective to be part of a court storming is to play a part in a movie you've seen a hundred times.
Maybe you're not Rudy, but you're the guy who hoisted him on your shoulders.
Without people like you, who would make up the crowd that Rocky had to fight through to get to his Adrian.
From the player's perspective it's a little different.
As a guard on the Fairleigh Dickinson team that went to the NCAA Tournament in 1998, Tedaryl Fason was party to court stormings both home and away.
Here, L.A.U., and when I was at L.A.U.
I didn't think we were going to make it home and on the bus, so it's definitely a scary feeling, but at the same time it's a good feeling after you win the game.
Ronald Stratton, Vice President of the NCAA, is concerned that college basketball celebrations are getting out of hand.
He doesn't want to wait until something tragic happens, as was the case with college football, where a student was actually killed when goalposts were dismantled after a victory.
He says the line between spectator and participant seems to be blurring.
They're trying to do whatever the can to bring the fan into the same experience as a competitor.
And by doing that there's some downsides to that.
I'm not sure that the crowd, particularly if it's in a frenzy, is caring about the safety of people trying to get on and off the court.
The Southeastern Conference has taken to fining schools if their fans storm the court.
In SEC arenas, such as Vanderbilt's, public address messages like this one are prominent.
(Soundbite of public address announcement)
Fans, also remember that all fans must stay off the playing court at the end of the game.
Violators are subject to arrest and the loss of future ticket privileges.
Yeah, it's sure looking that way.
The House is expected to vote today on the GOP tax bill with the Senate soon to follow.
And if that all happens, this would deliver President Trump his first big legislative victory about a year into office.
Let's bring NPR's national political correspondent Mara Liasson in to discuss this.
Hi, Mara.
Hi, Steve.
Republicans have the votes?
Republicans have the votes.
The Senate has been the big suspense here.
But right now, there are no known no votes.
We know they were down one vote because John McCain is going - is back in Arizona recovering from cancer treatment.
And Bob Corker and Susan Collins, who are two of the holdouts, said that they were going to vote yes.
Just in case, the vice president, Mike Pence, is delaying his trip to the Middle East in case he's needed.
But it looks like they're going to pass this bill.
Hasn't Corker been the center of some controversy because of a measure that was added at the last moment that seems potentially to benefit him?
Yes.
Corker was the only no vote last time, so there was a lot of question, why did he flip from no to yes?
But he insists that provision, which would've benefited people with big real estate holdings, like himself and the president, was not the reason that he flipped from no to yes.
Mara, I think if you're a Republican thinking about the politics of this, the good news for you is, you're about to pass this major legislation.
But the bad news for you is that you're about to pass this major legislation which is quite unpopular.
That's right.
This has been a long and winding path for this bill.
But with each tweak, the bill tilted a little more towards the wealthy - less real reform, more just plain old cuts.
And this is not the revenue-neutral tax reform once promised, not the kind of simplification once promised.
But it is a big test of supply-siders' belief that if you give tax cuts to the wealthy and corporations, it will help the economy.
Very few economists say that, but now we're going to test it.
And that is one of the reasons the bill is unpopular.
In the short term, many Americans will get a tax cut.
Of course, in the long term, those individual cuts expire, and the corporate cuts remain.
And the big questions for Republicans is, once Americans start to get the cuts, will they change their minds about this bill?
Will they feel more favorably toward it?
There're a lot of people in blue states, including in Republican districts, who are going to get a tax hike.
And Democrats are feeling pretty confident that they can drive home the message that Republicans are just doing favors for the wealthy.
So I'm just thinking through the next few days in Congress.
The House votes today on this huge tax bill, the Senate tonight or tomorrow - sometime pretty soon.
And that leaves them a whole couple of days to avoid a government shutdown by the end of the week.
Yes.
That's not a lot of days.
December 22 is the deadline.
It sounds like what Republicans probably will do is pass another short-term government funding bill.
That means they're going to kick the can down the road and revisit this whole government funding issue sometime in January.
The big question is what they're going to attach to this next temporary funding bill.
You know, Susan Collins, in return for her yes vote, was told that she was going to get some fixes to Obamacare.
The Obamacare mandate disappears in this tax bill.
It's eliminated.
But the question is, will the Obamacare fixes be attached to this government funding bill or not?
And then there's the bigger question about what to do with the DREAMers.
That's the Democrats' demand.
They're saying in order to pass government funding bill, they need some relief for those young people brought here illegally and had been protected from deportation by President Obama.
So...
So those are all questions.
But I think they're kicking the can down the road again.
Each of those questions a subject of its own discussion - or it could be.
Mara, thanks very much.
Thank you.
That's NPR's Mara Liasson.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
OK, now let's turn to the ongoing House investigation into Russia and the 2016 election.
Yeah, today, a House Intelligence Committee is going to hear from the FBI's No. 2 official.
That's Deputy Director Andrew McCabe.

His appearance - and we should say, it's going to be behind closed doors - comes as some Republicans have been stepping up their criticism of the FBI and special counsel Robert Mueller's team, alleging what they say is an anti-Trump political bias.
NPR's Ryan Lucas has been following all this, and he's in our studios.
Ryan, good morning.
Good morning.
